name.text: 10.2.3.1 Multiplication and division using polar coordinates

questiontext.text:
Multiplication and Division of Complex Numbers in Polar form

Now we finally get to the true power of the polar form of a complex number. There is necessary effort in converting from cartesian form to polar form but then work makes multiplication and division much more convenient. To see why, let us consider two complex numbers in polar form: \[z=r(\cos\theta +i\sin \theta)\qquad w=t(\cos\phi +i\sin\phi ).\] Then the product \(zw\) is calculated in the usual way \[\begin{aligned} zw&=[r\ (\cos\theta +i\sin \theta)][t\ (\cos\phi +i\sin\phi )]\\ &\equiv rt\ [\cos\theta\cos\phi -\sin\theta\sin\phi +i(\sin\theta\cos\phi +\cos\theta\sin\phi)]\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\quad\\ &\equiv rt\ [\cos (\theta +\phi)+i\sin (\theta + \phi )]\end{aligned}\] in which we have used the standard trigonometric identities \( \cos (\theta +\phi )\equiv \cos\theta\cos\phi -\sin\theta\sin\phi\qquad \sin (\theta + \phi )\equiv\sin\theta\cos\phi +\cos\theta\sin\phi.\) We see that in calculating the product that the moduli \(r\) and \(t\) multiply together whilst the arguments \(\text{arg}(z)=\theta\) and \(\text{arg}(w)=\phi\) add together.
